results.title: Fantasm (E)
results.creator_credit: Antony Ginnane, TLN Film Productions and Richard Bruce
results.brief_description: A soft-core ‘sexploitation’ film that took advantage of the new ‘R’ certificate rating that was introduced in Australia in the early seventies. The film is broken into ten segments that purport to portray the most common sexual fantasies of women in the seventies (a la Nancy Friday’s ‘My Secret Garden’), but which, in fact, are aimed squarely at the voyeuristic fantasies of the perceived male target audience. Each segment is introduced by a bumbling sexologist who parodies pop-Freudian psychiatry. Shot in Los Angeles over ten days using professional actors from the pornographic film industry (most famously John Holmes) for a production cost of $50,000, ‘Fantasm’ was a major box office success in Australia, its notoriety boosted by its banning in Queensland. The film is a good example of the kind of commercial feature film productions that were reviled by advocates of a ‘quality’ national cinema that said something about Australian identity. With the emergence of the ‘AFC genre’ in the mid-seventies this ‘other’ Australian cinema was largely erased from accounts of Australian film history. One of a number of soft-core sex films made in Australia through the seventies, ‘Fantasm’ reflected the sexually permissive attitudes of the times as well as illustrating how the ideals of the sexual revolution that promised sexual equality for men and women, were hijacked by heteromasculine models of sexual gratification. Written by Ross Dimsey. Cast includes John Bluthal, Dee Dee Levitt and Maria Arnold.

results.title: Fantasia Di Botticelli: La Calunnia
results.creator_credit: Romor Film and Carlo Carlo Ludovico Ragghianti
results.brief_description: The Florentine painter Sandro Botticelli was one of the greatest products of the Renaissance. His sinuous and telling outlines are so exceptionally decorative and expressive that they place his work amongst the finest creations in the history of art. His admiration of classical art is most powerfully evident in his recreation of “Calumny”, a lost masterpiece painted by a Greek artist Apelles in the third Century B.C. “The Calumny” is the centre point of the film around which the developing style of Botticelli is examined.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Romor Film and Carlo Carlo Ludovico Ragghianti

results.title: Fanny
results.brief_description:
Fanny has allowed Marius to leave her to become a sailor without telling him she was expecting his child. In order to avoid dishonor, Fanny’s mother, Honorine, is pushing the young woman to marry the wealthy and much older Panisse. Upon his return Marius learns about the wedding and the reason for so much haste. Careful to secure a future for ‘his’ grand son, Cesar, Marius’ father, persuades him to renounce any claim to the child. ‘Fanny’ is the second installement of Pagnol’s Marseille trilogy, started with ‘Marius’.

Credits: Producer, Roger Richebe ; director, Marc Allegret ; writer, Marcel Pagnol ; photography, Nicola Toporkoff ; music, Vincent Scotto, Georges Sellers ; producer’s assistants, Pierre Prevert, Yves Allegret.
Cast: Raimu, Orane Demazis, Pierre Fresnay, Fernand Charpin, Alida Rouffe.

results.title: Famous men and fair women
results.creator_credit: Ann Turner and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Pioneers of photography”.
Julia Margaret Cameron was an outstanding photographer of her day. Despite the restrictions of her social position, she became a recognised artist of portrait photography. Many notable individuals such as Charles Darwin and Alfred Lord Tennyson, were included amongst her subjects. The film gives insight into the social and cultural environment and the moral attitudes that affected concepts of beauty. Demonstrations of photographic procedures used during the 1800’s such as the sliding box camera, plates etc., is also shown. Narrated by Brian Coe.
